implementing: The Norwegian Refugee Council is an independent humanitarian organization helping people forced to flee, tarted their relief efforts after World War Two, humanitarian needs were critical. They still are # and NRC still there, protecting people forced toflee and supporting them as they build a new future. Today, NRC work in both new and protracted crises across 31 countries NRC provide camp management, food assistance, clean water, shelter, legal aid, and education. displaced people's rights and dignityin local communities, with national governments and in the international arena. NRC#s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre in Geneva is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country.

title: CO-Somalia Drought Response (Marisla)
description:
Somalia has experienced recurrent droughts since 2011 which have been increasingly exacerbated by climate change. Agro-pastoralistsand pastoralists have been badly affected by the 2019 drought which has caused widespread crop failure, water shortages, and depleted livestock levels.
More than 4.2 million people were estimated to be in need of humanitarian assistance in 2019, and the number ofpeople who are food insecure is expected to increase in the coming months.  This year#s severe drought has been caused by abnormally hot, dry conditions during January-March and the failure of the rains in April-June. Most households are already adopting negativecoping strategies to mitigate food insecurity, including reducing food intake. Poor transportation and market infrastructure make it difficult for pastoralists to access markets, and there are few fed markets to provide animals with nutrition when natural pastures are inadequate. Over 80% of livestock was lost as a result of the 2017 drought, and the population of livestock herds, essential for pastoralists# food and income, have not yet recovered.
The impact of the 2019 drought on the water and sanitation sector has beensignificant. Water supply (boreholes, shallow wells) is severely limited and the cost of accessing water has increased sharply, representing a severe burden on insufficient household income. Existing groundwater sources contain a highly mineralized content, rendering it unsuitable for drinking, but a prior Oxfam needs assessment showed that the vast majority of households in the project area do not treat their water. Open defecation remains common, increasing protection risks for women and girls who venture outside alone or during the night or move far from dwellings to known open defecation areas.
Oxfam aims to assist at least 500,000 affected peoplewith immediate food security and WASH programming along with resilience and recovery interventions to diminish the impact of recurring droughts on vulnerable populations. Oxfam will embed activities to strengthen the protection of women, men, boys, and girls within the EFSVL and WASH workstreams.

title: CO-DRA POC Development Process Somalia
description:
Core Humanitarian Standard, evidence-based and that meets needs holistically by integrating a triple nexus approach. This model will be peer-reviewed by other experts in the Global South. Once further funding is secured, it will become operational, with multiple organizations making varied, layered contributions to common outcomes according to their strengths # to ensure humanitarian responses uphold interwoven development and peace objectives and are thereby sustainable and transformative.
Additionally, the platform willproduce a robust operating procedure for its Anticipatory Response Fund, which serves as an emergency response mechanism/crisis modifier. Many INGOs, including Oxfam in Myanmar and Bangladesh, have successfully piloted this response mechanism with local partners.Upon request by local partners, the Somalia Joint Response is also piloting this mechanism with local partners in 2020, and all SOMJR INGOs have included a crisis modifier in their budgets in 2020. The Anticipatory Response Fund serves as a means for local humanitarian partners to quickly access funding to respond to sudden crises and emergencies. The fund's aim is to address funding gaps andensure quick access to emergency funding for local responders. The fund will build oncurrent initiatives in country to promote local humanitarian leadership and preparedness, and deliver on commitments made in the Grand Bargain and Charter for Change by donor andNGO signatories. It will also identify strengths and areas for capacity development in relation to emergency response in Somalia The operating procedure for the Anticipatory Response Fund will include triggers and related protocols, such that a pilot test of triggers, collaboration mechanisms and protocols can take place ahead ofthe humanitarian response windows, in the second half of 2020.
Beyond the pilot phase, these actions will lay the foundations for a response mechanism that is pre-emptive and therefore efficient and highly responsive # improving the quality of locally-led humanitarian response in Somalia and Somaliland. Delivering on the ambition statement (i.e. development of above-mentioned model for humanitarian programming and operating procedures) will contribute to all four DRA strategic priorities: 1) more effective support for locally-led responses by supporting Nexus as locally-led platform; 2) innovation and learning by generating knowledge outputs and new ways of working; 3) collaboration for increased effectiveness by bringing together a wide range of localactors with coverage of all 9 regions of Somalia and Somaliland; and 4) more accountable humanitarian action by giving voice and decision making power to local organisations and adding rigor through South-South peer review.

title: CO-Enhancing Resilience in Somaliland II
description:
Specific objective/ Outcome:  Sustainably improve food security and livelihoods of Somali people, households, communities through effective risk management, protection of productive assets, improved governance of resilience structures, and promotion of innovations and evidence based programming.
Intermediary Outcome 1: Improved capacity of households to implement disaster risk management and positive coping strategies to mitigate the immediate effect of exposure to shock.
Intermediary Outcome 2: Improved capacity of individuals, households and communities to adhere to positive development trajectories; despite exposures to shocks and utilize strategies designed to allow adaptation to rapid and slow on-set hazards.
Intermediary Outcome 3: Improved capacity to engage in strategies for sustainable livelihoods and economic growth to enhance food security and resilience

title: CO-Somalia Desert Locust Response Projec
description:
Specific objective:  To curb the spread of Desert Locust, pprotect and recover Livelihoods of the people affected by Locust disaster in Somaliland and Puntland.
Result 1: Improved locust control mechanisms and capacitate/enable government and local community to minimize negative effects on livelihoods of people affected by desert locust.
Result 2: Reduced impact of desert locust and support early livelihood recovery through provision critical agriculture inputs and livestock fodder.
Activities
1.1. Support 10 community mobilization campaigns and trainings at ground level, on locust control.
1.2. 600 people undertake mechanical control (digging trenches and driving hopper bands into them) through cash for work
1.3. 3 community awareness campaigns through media outlets, reaching 24 villages with an average population of 350 HHs each (8500HHs to be reached through awareness and outreach on locust).
1.4        Conduct one baseline, and one Post Distribution Monitoring.

title: Increasing  Agricultural Production
description:
Oxfam has rehabilitated dozens of boreholes in Sool and Sanaag region, most of those water structure has solar system in place. Oxfam#s assessment found pout that some of those structures are not used by people due to varying reasons. Oxfam EFSVL and WASH team discussed this issue and propose we combine water and agricultural production. Oxfam will support ministry of agriculture to assess 6-7 water points in those two regions aimed to start agricultural production. The government will mobilize communities and familiarizethem agricultural production. It is expected that linking existing water sites to agriculture will improve nutritional. Mionistry of agriculture will enhane agricultural practices by introducing agriculture around those water points. The ministry will provide seeds, knowledge regularly using its field staff.
Nutrition-Sensitive Agriculture is good-based approach to agricultural development that puts nutritionally rich foods, dietary diversity and food fortification at the heart of overcoming malnutrition and micronutrientdeficiencies. This assignment focuses on the utilization of water resource for agriculture sector to improve the nutritional value of foods for good nutrition, health and productivity, and social significance of farming and supporting rural livelihood specially that pregnant, lactating women and child.
# The main objective of this mission is to investigate the suitability of borehole water resource for utilization for irrigation purpose.
# Understanding Perception of the community for benefiting water for agriculture purpose
# The MOAD consultants will observe the appropriateness of nature of land (soil type, topography, soil nutrient) for crop production and predict the method of irrigation that could be used.
# During the field exercise, the consultants will analyze the proper ways of community water allocation for domestic use, animal watering and irrigation.
# The consultants will investigate the current situation of agricultural production status and level of nutrition of beneficiaries# community.
# Consultants will have soil and water samples

implementing: Mandate of the Somaliland ministry of agricultural development is to develop and implement of agriculture sector policies, rules and regulations, formulating sector development plans, programmers and projects, documentation and registration of agricultural land,agricultural research. Establishment, management and maintenance of agriculture databases and dissemination to stakeholders, promotion of increased agricultural production, ensuring the country#s food security. Promotion of sustainable utilization and management of natural agricultural resources, ensuring food quality and safety, provision and coordination of agriculture extension and othersupport services. Coordination, Monitoring and Evaluation of agricultural programmers, projects and activities, agricultural humanresource development and management, promoting agricultural marketing, awareness raising and agri-business. Guiding regulations ofimport and export of agricultural products and controlling unwanted seeds to avoid pests and diseases effect food production of thecountry. Consultation of agricultural community to the control of the pests and diseases effect food production of the country.

description:

title: CO-Somalia Locust Control Measures
description:
Oxfam has been working in Somalia for over 40 years, working with Somali people and organisations implementing humanitarian, resilience and development programmes. Humanitarian response focuses on WaSH, EVFSL and Protection.
Oxfam has made a lot of gains through humanitarian resilience programmes which are likely to be eroded if the desert locust menace is uncontrolled. Oxfam will therefore capitalise and work with the existing community structures such as Early Warning Committees, Government line ministries, FAO and other stakeholders on the preventive and control measures.
Oxfam will prioritize safeguarding livelihoods focusing on cash intervention and locust control measures.

A total of 1,056 people in coastal areas of Sool region will be reachedby the project and supported toprotect and recover their livelihoods.

Oxfam has vast experience in implementing conditional and unconditional cash transfer approaches in WASH, EVFSL programmes. The project will specifically focus on the Cash for Work(CfW) approach as it not only empowers individuals to spend based on their priority needs but also focuses on revamping community assets. CfW will therefore stimulate the recovery of the local economy by creating short-term work, reintroduce income flow,supporting local businesses through the purchase worktools while also encouraging households to purchase food and non-food items locally. The trench digging will involve large numbers of the population and will be designed to encourage the integration and participation of women and other marginalized groups in an area thus benefitting the entire community and not just a few individuals.

The project will support communities to address locust spread by burying them in trenches excavated through cash for work. A total of 1,056 people will dig 26 km of trenches and drive hopper bands through cash for work, this task will continue for 30 days, 15 days per month starting in mid-March 2020. This task is expected to minimize hopper bands probability to turn to dangerous swarm level while at the same time communities will be able to access cash to help them address food insecurity situation at household level.

Oxfam will closely cooperate with the Somaliland Ministry of agriculture

title: CO-COVID-19 Help Line
description:
a. Receive and make calls to the application through existing three-digit toll free short code.
b. Manages region-based calls and direct to appropriate call centers in the six Somaliland regions.
c. Customize existing application to handle multiple calls at the same time.
d. Provide an option for callers to access up to date information on the virus based on the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines through toll free number (Telesom will cover Short code and calling minutes).
e. Provide Symptoms screening checker to all callers to answer few questions over the phone to determine whether they at risk and provide appropriate advice.
f.  Speak to caller center operator for further information and support.
2. Assisting capacitate the existing call center in Hargeisa and establish additional 5 call centers with three health workers manning each call center.
3. Train the call center staff to manage the help line platform, receive calls, process audio messages and call back people who could not get through. Provide regular reports to committee and potential high risks cases for action when the times comes.
4. Maintain and support the platform for the duration of the pandemic.
5. The ministry would also create group of their health works system to send out rapid messages.

The key feature of the service isthe ability to handle multiple calls, leave voice messages if the caller can#t get through, symptoms screening and provision of up to date information as per the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines.
A total of 18 call center staff volunteers from the Ministry of Health will be trained through a two days workshop in Hargeisa to train them on the platform and dealing with callers during this difficult time. Three call center volunteers will be selected from each of the six main regions in Somaliland including Marodijeex, Awdal, Saxil, Todgheer, Sool and Sanaag. Volunteers will through shifts and lines will be closed from 5pm each day and opens at 7am.During this time, system will direct all callers to voice mail system. It is expected that there will be large number of spam messages and the platform will be designed to handle spam callers.

4. Maintain and support the platform for the duration of the pandemic.
5. The ministry would also create group of their health works system to send out rapid messages.

The key feature of the service isthe ability to handle multiple calls, leave voice messages if the caller can#t get through, symptoms screening and provision of up to date information as per the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines.
A total of 18 call center staff volunteers from the Ministry of Health will be trained through a two days workshop in Hargeisa to train them on the platform and dealing with callers during this difficult time. Three call center volunteers will be selected from each of the six main regions in Somaliland including Marodijeex, Awdal, Saxil, Todgheer, Sool and Sanaag. Volunteers will through shifts and lines will be closed from 5pm each day and opens at 7am.During this time, system will direct all callers to voice mail system. It is expected that there will be large number of spam messages and the platform will be designed to handle spam callers.

title: CO-Desert Locust - Joint Response
description: The Desert Locust Joint Response is a 6 month emergency response project focusing on FSL and Cash interventions to control the spread of locust and support communities (agropastoralists and pastoralists) in coping with the loss of livelihoods due to locust invasions. All activities will be accompanied by COVID-19 WASH preparedness interventions, focusing on Public Health Promotion and the distribution of hygiene items. SOS Somaliland is the lead for this Joint Response (DRA). Oxfam will deliver the project with partners Candlelight and KAALO, who will work in Eastern Somaliland and Puntland (Togdheer, Sool, Nugal). Oxfam will respond in Awdal and Togdheer.

title: CO-COVID-19 Pandemic Support
description:
Description of the crisis (including number of affected, timeline, number of affected Oxfam has reached to date etc):
COVID-19 (Coronavirus acute respiratory disease) was first identified in late 2019 in Wuhan in Hubei province, China, and has since spread globally, resulting in the ongoing pandemic. While there are so far only seven laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Somalia (first case: 16 March 2020), it must be noted there are no testing facilities and tests are currently sent to South Africa. Results are received after two weeks. The country has only 15 intensive care unit beds and ranks 194th out of 195 in the Global Health Security Index. Over a third of Somalis do not have enough clean, safe water to meet their daily needs, let alone for more frequent preventive handwashing. It goes without saying that an outbreak of COVID-19 in Somalia would have a devastating impact on vulnerable communities who already suffer from drought, conflict and most recently, locust invasion. 6.3 million Somalis are food insecure, 2.1 million internally displaced. The below activities would provide Oxfam Somalia and our partners with a top-up to the 50,000 GBP recently received through the CAT Fund.
Project description / activities (including numbers to be reached):
An additional 100,000 GBP (50% as loan, 50% as grant) will enable Oxfam and our partners to scale up the WASH preparedness activities as well as support partner Shaqodoon on extending the COVID-19 helpline to Somalia#s Puntland State. Shaqodoon are currently in the process of completing the set-up of the helpline in Somaliland (with support from the current CAT Fund grant); to be launched by 11th April. The helpline in Puntland willfollow the same process as in Somaliland: Shaqodoon will develop the system and link it to a toll-free Coronavirus hotline providedby Puntland#s Ministry of Health. The Ministry of Health will work closely with WHO and identify health personnel who will be trained in receiving and processing calls. Shaqodoon will provide pre-recorded health messages, on-site technical support and data analysis/dashboards for the Ministry.

The remaining amount will be utilised to scale up COVID-19 preparedness activities in Somaliland and Puntland, in collaboration with partners. Itwill also be used to top-up partners# crisis modifiers from other donors to make theircontribution in this fight, more meaningful. Activities include set-up of handwashing points in settlements, purchase and distribution of hygiene kits to IDP communities, dispatching mobile teams to disinfect busy public areas and purchase of HTH chlorine pumps for disinfection.

50,000 people will be reached by Oxfam#s and partners# WASH COVID-19 preparedness activities.
Shaqodoon through the Ministry of Health of Puntland hopes to reach a majority of Puntland#s phone users with COVID-19 information sharing and prevention messaging.

title: CO-Covid-19 Protection Intervention
description:
As part of COVID19 preparedness and response  Oxfam and Shaqodoon local partner in collaboration with ministry of health and Telesom company have jointly set up and launched an interactive COVID-19 call center in Hargeisa. The call center plays a vital role in the dissemination of up-to-date and accurate and reliable information to the public, it provides prerecorded prevention guidelines; audio-based symptoms pre-screening options; counseling and medical assistance from health professionals and referrals to the emergencyand quarantine centers nearby. The center also feeds the government a way of tracking suspect cases information for emergency action and is alternative mechanism  for those have not physical access to government health facilities related to COVID. The call centerhas a toll free 24/7 available short code number (988) accessible from all over the country with 14 dedicated call agents who handle and process calls and voice messages, 2 professional doctors available for the management of suspect cases who provide counseling on daily bases to the callers and 2 technical assistance.
The call center receives 294,427 calls since its inception. Shaqodoon sends daily reports of the center including information of the suspect cases to the ministry of health to inform their daily plans regarding COVID19.
some of the Major project activities are :
- Supporting your partners in adapting to Covid-19 situation so that they can continue to provide protection services
- Adapting referrals to the newsituation # remotely?
- Supporting Protection committees to adapt their activities/ prepare for activities during lockdown (e.g. material needed, technical advice)
- Preparing to stay in touch with communities if movement restrictions get stricter (e.g.communication systems needed)
- Remote protection monitoring

title: CO-Response of Locust Infestation
description:
On 2nd February 2020 the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation of the Federal Government of Somalia has declared a national emergency (see press statement in attachment) in view of the current Desert Locust upsurge that poses a major threat to Somalia#sfragile food security situation. Food sources for people and their livestock are at risk. The Desert Locust swarms are uncommonly large and consume huge amounts of crops and forage.
According to locust office of the Ministry of Agriculture and HADMA  latest report, there were huge swarm of Desert locust from Yemen that at the end September 2019 laid eggs in many locations in Somaliland. Despite controlefforts, a serious and widespread desert locust outbreak is threatening crops and pasture across Northern Somali regions. Accordingto experts, this is the worst outbreak in over 25 years in Somalia.

The situation has rapidly deteriorated in January 2020, as weather conditions have been unusually conductive to the spread of the pest. After cyclone Pawanmade landfall in early December 2019, flooding across the Horn of Africa created favourable breeding conditions for desert locusts. These conditions allow the breeding until June 2020 and could lead to 500 times more locust with the formation of large numbers of swarm as FAO indicated in their latest Appeal .
Desert Locust breeding is ongoing in Somaliland, Puntland and Galmudug (Mudug). An estimated 70,000 hectares of land has been invaded by hoppers and breeding adults. Once they mature the locusts areexpected to migrate in swarms and move south towards the Ethiopian border area of Somaliland as well as Jubaland, Southwest State and Hirshabelle. These swarms will be at their most destructive stage and pose a very severe risk to Deyr season food and fodder production.
Mating adults, hoppers and swarms have been detected in Northwest Somalia (between Bulhar and Silil). Hoppers and immature adults were reported on the Northwest plateau and a swarm was detected between Burao and the Ethiopian border. Hopper bands were also reported south of Bossaso, south of Las Anod (near the Ethiopian border) and in Galmudug (near Galkayo). More swarms are likely to form along the Northwest coast and plateau, which may migrate to Djibouti, Eastern Ethiopia and SouthernSomalia.
Crop and pastures have already been damaged in Somalia impacting negatively onagropastoral and pastoral households. In December 2019, it was reported that a huge number of desert locust (still at the stage of hopper bands) hatched in differentbreeding areas of Somaliland, such as coastal areas and farming land, posing a new devastating threat to crops and pasture lands.

title: CO-Covid-19  Spread Prevention In Somali
description:
Oxfam and our partners believe that accurate and reliable information on Covid-19 will save lives: currently, we are already responding and reaching more than 40,000 people directly with WASH services and more than 650,000 people in Somaliland and Puntland via the Covid-19 helplines this proposal seeks to support.  Toll-free Covid-19 helplines our partner Shaqodoon is running in the Ministries of Health in Somaliland and Puntland have been launched in mid-April and beginnning of May respectively. The call centres utilize an interactive voice response system providing up to date information related to Covid-19 to the community. People can call the hotline and receive WHO-approved pre-recorded messages on COVID-19, check symptoms, and also talk to a healthofficers if they wish to doso. They can also leave a voicemail and will be called back. The system can be accessed free of charge through mobile phones for callers using a 3-digit shortcode.
The Somaliland hotline has registered more than 651,366 callsso far (as of 19 May), highlighting the thirst of people across Somaliland for accurate and reliable information on Covid-19.  A number of risk cases have been identifiedthrough the helplines already, and people tested as a result of their call and guidance received. Shaqodoon is highlighting common misinformation on Covid-19 gathered through calls as well as stats on calls, follow-up and regional origin of callers on dashboards which support the Ministry of Health and humanitarian partners in addressing needs in a timely manner. They also produce weekly dashboards to provide the Ministry of Health with an overview of calls, levels of (mis-)information per region and necessary follow-up.

This project would support Shaqodoon in extending the helpline service in collaboration with the Ministries of Health for another 2months until June/July, reaching a majority of the population in Puntland and Somaliland (at least 60% of the population) with accurate and timely information, guidance and symptoms checking, while at the same time ensuring call center staff and Ministry of Health officials receive adequate protection and safe programming support to deal with sensitive data and critical cases.  Their work will be accompanied by the installment of innovative hands-free handwashing stations designed and produced in the TVET centres of partner Havoyoco. These measures will reach another 30,000 people across Somaliland.

title: CO-COVID-19 Oxfam Somalia Response
description:
In this part of the world where displacement and utmost poverty are prevalent with no properly
functioning health systems, it is hard to imagine how adversely impactful a COVID-19 outbreak will be.
People are already extremely vulnerable to bear yet another distressing crisis. While all countries need to
respond to COVID-19, countries with existing humanitarian crisis coupled with weak governance are
particularly vulnerable. When COVID-19 affects countries with protracted humanitarian crises like
Somalia/land, vulnerable populations, particularly women headed households, the disabled and the
elderly living in overcrowded camps or informal urban settlements will be highly vulnerable to the disease
and its social and economic impacts unless support is given on preventative measures.The number of
people in need of humanitarian assistance in Somalia, around 5.2 million currently, will likely sharply
increase in the event of COVID-19 outbreak making the already fragile situation much worse. The Locust
infestation is another evolving crisis andif not addressed will also have significant impact on the food
security and livelihoods of the people.
COVID-19 crisis will have a different and far-reaching impact on poor people, especially the vulnerable.
Anyone can be exposed to the virus but the poor are most vulnerable as they lack financial and social
protections. Overcrowded IDP settlements and poor urban slums are also going to be the places where
disease can spread easily and quickly. To effectively address the urgent and acute humanitarian dimension
of the crisis, we need to frame that within our understanding of how inequality plays out. Women will be
as susceptible to getting infected by the virus but their need for support is greater because, as in any crisis,
women including elderly women, bear the greater responsibility of caring for the family and making both
ends meet. Women#s multiple burdens of needing to contribute to the household income while also taking
care of the young, theelderly and the sick mean they have the longest days, the shortest rest and the
highest stress, making them easy targets of disease.
Containment measures and their economic fallout are likely to hurt more than the disease itself, and for
longer. Restrictions on movement and market access will affect many households# income and coping
strategies in Somalia/land, including households who were relatively well off before the pandemic. As well
as short term support we need to consider howto provide support to those affected over the longer term.

title: CO-COVID-19 Spared Reduction in Somalia
description:
6. Planned activities
a. WASH
- Improve personal hygiene and social distancing practice through awareness raising  on Covid-19
- Install functional handwashing centers in main IDP camp entrances, health facilities, main market areas with higher risk and other selected areas.
- Support for disinfection of screening centers, isolation centers, health facilities and other priority areas.
- Purchase and distribute hygiene kits to promote handwashing with soap at household level.
- Emergency water supply and construction of latrines for isolation, health facilities, and IDPs/host communities with water shortages (cash to access water)
b. FSL
- Support and improve roll out of inclusive social assistance through a minimum of four months# remote cash and/or vouchers, delivered to female headed households
- Livelihood inputs and technical assistance to support vulnerable population groups affected by the pandemic
c. Protection
- Provide protection support  to COVID-19 call center in Puntland.
- Provide protection and safe programming  training for frontline health workers operating in Oxfam areas of intervention and call center teams.
- Support existing community based protection structures e.g community volunteers, women#s forums to conduct community level awareness raisings on COVID-19 prevention provide PPE kits.
- Carry out specific service map that covers  information and service delivery of COVID19. An update on protection and emergency services will also be included e.g availability, accessibility etc.

title: CO-COVID-19 Pandemic II
description:
# Solarization of two existing water sources   in Baki and Saylac districts of Awdal benefiting more than 10,000 people and their livestock. Awdal is one of the regions affected by COVID19 as it connects Somaliland to Djibouti. The majority of people are dependent pity trades, small scale irrigation, and livestock, most of these activities have been affected, and communities reported a reduction of income. Existing water supply sources are mainly powered by a diesel generator that are purchased from the tariffs collected from the users. Associated water tariffs are sky rocking as access to diesel has reduced as restrictions are imposed on public transport. Out of the many strategic water sources, two sources are selected, supplying water for villages affected by COVID19 in Somaliland. Oxfam will install a solar system for these wells, and the action will reduce the cost of water tariff and increase community use of water for different purposes include handwashing.
# Build the capacity of the WASH committees managing the solarizedse water sources by providing necessary tools and training them on both technical skill and financial management. This action will be led by the ministry of water department of scheme management. As we mobilize for the two sources an additional two boreholes within the sameareas will also be invited for the training. These will help to maximize use of expert time, cover nearby villages with capacity building plan and increase value for money by targeting more with same budget.
# Support Somaliland Ministry of Water Development to ministry of water to finalize   the design and construction for WASH facilities to be shared with all WASH Cluster members in Somaliland. The national WASH cluster has prioritized this action as per the request from ministry and Oxfam will contribute for this action. The budget will be used to cover some of the consultancy fees or provide expertise to help them finalize the work.
# Provide safeprogramming training for WaSH committees, district administrations, women groups other key stakeholders including traditional leaders    .
# Protection awareness raising including community discussions on protection impact to address stigma and promotion of the call centre hotline   (already operational) to increase access to covid19 services for affected communities    .
# Government capacity building/strengthen social safety net system in Somaliland : we will build the capacity of the government to be able to lead and coordinate Somaliland safety net program. Somalia launched safety net project called bahnano at Mogadishu but this has not been cascaded to Somaliland and Puntland. The government staff responsible for this are unable to run safety net due to their limited capacity. The project will target technical staff from the government and create enabling environment in the form of institutional capacity building including training of key staff, support implementation of beneficiaries selection and running coordination mechanisms smoothly.  Oxfam Somalia is implementing social safety net activity under GFFO top up. Under this activity the project aims improving supports to HHs in urban areas particularly COVID19 affected poorest or most vulnerable to prevent them to fall to poverty and destitution trap, manage COVID19 economic and social shocks and advance their lives <(>&<)> livelihoods. The government capacity in Somaliland on social safety net is to grow and as part of appeal fund, Oxfam will contribute to strengthening/establishing social protection system that leads COVID19 response project. Oxfam will partner with Somaliland Ministry of Employment, Social and Family as socialprotection responsible government body. Somaliland government capacity is yet to grow and this project will address this gap while also coordinating with other implementing agencies to strengthen their capacity to be able to lead social assistance and provide at scale in the future to its society as a right. The project creates an opportunity for governments to become the standard responders to large scale crises.

title: SOCIAL INNOVATION PROJECTS
description:
Harhub in partnership with Oxfam is launching a social innovation challenge to tackle most pressing social issues. The partners areaiming to harness the innovations of young people in Somaliland and beyond particularly social entrepreneurs, developers, changemakers, and health practitioners keen on bringing game-changing solutions to most vital social challenges focusing on in the areas of agriculture, technology, SDGs, health, food, education, and energy. The partners believe that tackling these complex issues will require diverse skill sets, backgrounds, effort and innovation. Harhub will be prioritizing innovations which may already be proven but will reach new heights of interest within the industry given the right support from Harhub, or innovations which are new ideas and concepts, but might need some tuning to fit the requirements of potential customers.
Through a competitive process, Harhub will reachout to 10k youth through social media promotions to apply the program for three weeks. Harhub is expected to receive quite big and competitive projects. Whilst applicants are ongoing, Harhub will create mentors’ criteria and hire 3 mentors to lead selection and the Bootcamp. All the submitted projects will be evaluated by the mentors based on the solutions’ unique value proposition, social impact, visibility, technical viability, and the individuals’/teams’ ability and capability to scale the solution.

In total, the mentors will then select twenty most advanced and innovative projects to attendthe two full days Bootcamp to be held at Harhub. The Bootcamp will be a high-energy workshop focused on rapid ideation, refinement, and prototyping of solutions. It is a space to generate, iterate on, and test ideas for social impact, foster a culture ofinnovation through experimentation, collaboration, and expand a community of social impact innovators. In the final event, twenty finalists will pitch their solutions for a chance to win grant funding, incubation, and mentorship scheme. The top three projects will be awarded a grant fund to their projects at Harhub with all support of providing free incubation and mentorship to develop, validate, execute and scale their solutions

implementing: Har-Hub was founded , after realizing that the unemployment rate among those under 30 in Somaliland, who comprise 70% of the population, is 67% they have decided to identify ways they can help young people access opportunities and create jobs for the one another, Now they have programs and services tailored that allow young innovators and entrepreneurs to create, build, scale and sustain social ventures that tackle the communities most pressing issues such as unemployment.

title: Women In Tech
description:
Somaliland has a population of over 3.7 million. According to Somaliland’s Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs, UNDP and the World Bank reports, over 70% of Somaliland’s population is under the age of 30. The unemployment rate for youth aged 15 to 30 is 67% - one of the highest rates in the world. Among young women, it is even estimated at 74%. Youth in Somaliland are not just the future ofthe country, they are also the majority.
With 67% of the youth being out of work, the high unemployment rate forthe youth remains abig challenge in Somaliland, and this rate is even higher for young women. The unemployment rate for young women in the country is estimated to be 74%. Due to the insecurity over the last two decade and stagnant economic growth, jobs have not been created at a rate that is able to match the growth of the youth population.
Women often face stiff competition during business pitching/competitions and often shy away to compete with their fellow men or observe stigmatization. This conceptwill bridge this gap by specifically earmarking this Women in Tech competition for young women tech savvies to compete among each other.
To achieve a long lasting and sustainable economic and social transformation in the country, we must empower young women, create opportunities for prosperity and provide them with the necessary tools and resources.
Hence Innovate Ventures (IV) in partnership and collaboration with Oxfam aim to support, accelerate and grow the Somali women startup scene and accelerate the growth of women startups in technology to help them create employment opportunities, and improve the investment climate in the country

implementing: Innovate Ventures is the leading start-up accelerator and technology fund in Somaliland and Somalia. Innovate Ventures mission is to develop tech-based businesses in Somalia and Somaliland, support the next wave of Somali entrepreneurs, and grow the nascent start-up ecosystem in the country. Innovate Ventures is the leading Somali startup accelerator and early-stage startup fund supporting ambitious startups who use technology to change the world. Through our accelerator programme we invest in and support great teams withcool ideas to help build a world-class business through an intensive three-month programme.

title: CO-Locust Response II
description: The aim to undertake pastoral field school demonstration site linked to mechanical locust control community level. Oxfam will establish one demo site in El-afweyn. Pastoral field schools participants will participate interactive on site learning events for a period of 5-10 days. Essential assorted tools and to be procured in advance by Oxfam. Oxfam staff will conduct the training in collaboration with ministry of agriculture. A total of 60 people will benefit this project who are invited from near by locations who are locust prone sites and equipped with mechanical control skills. Preparation of raised beds include also the inputs essential for this task

title: CO-Local Humanitarian Leadership (Nexus)
description:
6.3 million people are currently in need of humanitarian assistance across Somalia and Somaliland, with 2.6 million internally displaced and an estimated 1 million displaced in nearby countries. Whilst the deepening climate crisis exacerbates needs, Somalia and Somaliland are becoming increasingly stable, as persistent war gives way to erratic conflict and increasing capacity of government. Despite this, international actors face the obstacles of persistent issues of restricted access and highly challenging security circumstances. Local actors by contrast are able to transcend these issues and to guide interventions with nuanced local knowledge. This represents an opportunity to lead and deliver humanitarian aid locally. Somalia is one of the countries where a Joint Response to a protracted crisis under the DRA (SOMJR) is being implemented. With the changing context towards greater local leadership, the SOMJR already focuses on widening the space for local responders in humanitarian emergencies and decision-making fora. However, the Joint Response is fully led by INGOs, which inevitably creates unequal power dynamics that can negatively impact on the meaningful localization sought by local partners in Somalia. The protracted crisis situation, the long-standing presence of the DRA in Somalia, as well as the emergence of strong local humanitarian actors present the reality in which this PoC process can be carried out, and where an innovative pilot Joint Response focusing on meaningful localization would beworth exploring.
The Nexus Platform is an innovative response to the need for joined-up, localized responses at the triple nexus of humanitarian, development and peace programming: intervening to deliver coordinated outputs in all 3 spheres, which is essential in the Somali context, where climate shocks and conflict perpetually undermine humanitarian and development outcomes and deepen humanitarian crises. Although specifically tackled in the Somali context here – climate shocks and conflict are global causes of ongoing humanitarian crises, making the Nexus Platform’s approach pertinent to challenges at the triple nexus in parallel circumstances. Comprised of nine local NGOs (footprint 30m USD), Oxfam andSave the Children International and entirely locally led, the platform is operational across every region of Somalia and Somaliland. The platform is built upon principles of South-to-South learning and civil society strengthening, whereby expertise is openly exchanged between member organizations to build a consortium that is more than the sum of its parts. Humanitarian response is central tothe platform’s nascent phase. The platform envisions both multisectoral humanitarian response and the development of an Anticipatory Response Mechanism – utilisingthe platform’s breadth of local access to trigger pre-emptive early action. The platform urgently needs – and is invested in developing – a model for its humanitarian programme areas through a PoC process which will allow the platform to rethink conventional humanitarian approaches that are particularly open to question in contexts such as Somalia. The process used to develop this model will be additionally adapted for the development of the platform’s ways of working in the development and peace spheres:whilst humanitarian actions are the platform’s immediate priority in its current scope of work, programs exemplifying locally-led decision making are planned in community development, government and civil society strengthening, women’s empowerment and other areas across the triple nexus and these will require their own guiding PoC processes.

implementing: Save the Children has worked in Somalia/Somaliland since 1951 when set up a vocational school for orphaned boys in Somaliland. From the early 1970s They went a step further and began providing emergency assistance to communities in Somalia For nearly 65 years,They have been there whenever a crisis has hit. In 2017, their work in Somalia/Somaliland reached 2,814,381 people - 1,717,809 being children with Health, Nutrition, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), Education, Food Security and Livelihoods (FSL) and Child Protection services. As Well as long-term development work, They scaled up to respond to humanitarian spikes caused by drought, floods and cholera outbreaks. They have worked closely with the Government and supported policy makers and communities across Somalia and Somaliland to develop and approve policies and systems that will ensure a protective environment for children. They believe in building resilience amongst communities in Somalia/Somaliland and are committed to doing so through: • Provision of basic social services in education, health, and protection • Strengthening of government capacity to deliver such services • Working with communities and children to promote their rights. For the past 60 years They have delivered life-saving humanitarian services to children, and promoted the delivery of basic services to children through longer-term development programs

title: CO-Response To  Cyclone Crisis in Somali
description:
The program will be achieved through focusing on unconditional cash transfer transfers targeting the most vulnerable IDPs and host communities affected by COVID 19 economically and exacerbated by GATI cyclone, based on the food consumption scoring and loss of livelihood assets. This intervention forms approximately 70% of the total cash transfer programming under Oxfam’s overall response and will be implemented directly by Oxfam by engaging electronic financial service provider in Puntland via mobile phones. Beneficiarieswho don’t possess Sim-cards will receive them as part of this response and be trained on its usage. The overall Oxfam food securityintervention which this contributes towards will include additional emergency livelihoods and recovery elements including cash for work interventions to rebuild destroyed feeder roads.Oxfam targets households that meet the critical food insecurity criteria takingintoconsideration gender-differentiated needs. The selection criteria will be discussed with thetarget women, men, boys and girls toensure fairness of the selection process. Usually, women are registered as beneficiaries and the head of the household for cash transfers. At times we find that some polygamous households are includedduring registration stage and this is addressed during verification, ensuring that the most vulnerable HH are Commented [AC12]: In addition to these activities DEC funds can also be used to coverany hygiene promotion activities/hygiene kits, COVID messaging, PPE for staffif needed?Commented [MH13R12]: We Have some PPE in thefield, Moses to add purchase of some PPE in the budget
targeted, in collaboration with community leaders. Female-headed households are the most affected as they do not have access to meaningful household assets such as livestock, or other sources of income. In Bari region, priorities for livelihood regeneration activities are different for women and men. Oxfam will deliver emergency food security interventions through cash grants for the most vulnerable people, while supporting household income by strengtheningand diversifying livelihoods through other projects. Oxfam's programming since March 2017 has successfully diversified the source of livelihoods in traditional pastoralist communities in Somaliland with plansto replicate this expereicnce in Puntland. This intervention will help vulnerable households to have some disposable income which they can use to purchase or meet their household food needs.Most vulnerable community members that will be most in need of the emergency assistance through this action will be identified through participatory mapping exercises conducted at village level through specific exercises including well-being rankings, vulnerability mapping, food consumption score, household purchasing power, among others. Gender will be consideredwhen selecting households to help reduce the additional burden on women headedhouseholds. The criteria shall be clearly explained to the selection committee/panel prior toselection, with clearcommunication on what beneficiaries will be entitled to during the project, to avoid unrealistic expectations.

title: CO-EFSL & WASH Based COVID-19 Response
description: Somalia is one  of the  most  fragile and complex humanitarian crises in  the world. The country is emerging from more than three decades of conflicts with weak formal government systems since the collapse of the central  governmentin  the  early  1990s.Decades  ofarmed  conflicts  coupled  with  recurrent  drought conditions,  famine,  persistent  food  insecurity,  protracted  population  displacement  as  well  as  seasonal flooding  have left the country suffering one of the world’s worst humanitarian  situations.  The southern Somalia  has  been  the  worst  affected  with  the  region  experiencing  cycles  of  conflict  that  have  destroyed legitimate  institutions  and  created  widespread  vulnerability.  While  situation  was  dire  alreadydueto protracted  conflicts and drought, COVID 19 pandemic emergence detoriorated both health and livelihood sources of Somali community. In DEC phase 2, Oxfam plans to provide an integrated WASH and food security project to support emergency food  crises and  support  recovery  of livelihoods lost  due  to  drought  or  COVID  19  pandemic  in  Puntland, Jubaland and Somaliland administrative regions of Somalia. EFSVL Component: The project will addresshumanitarian needs of the IDPs, poor urban and returnees and will support cash and voucher assistance(CVA) to people affected by triple threats of conflict, drought and COVID 19 economically. This will be complemented to supportingLivelihood restoration for women groups affected  by  COVID  pandemic toenable  them to resume  or  establish  viable  livelihood options  intended  to provide  sustainable  livelihood  opportunities  for  affected  IDPs,  returnees  and  host  community  in  target 11regions of Somalia. This outcome will alleviate the sufferingof 6,780 people from extreme effects of COVID 19 i mpact and improve their food security situation. WASH Outcomes: A total of 8000people are expected to benefit from rehabilitation of three strategic water points  coupled  by  hygiene  and  promotion activities.  COVID  19  awareness  raising  will  be  conducted  for 60,000people  in  all  target  regions  of  the  project  with  the  aim  of  reducing  spread  of  this  pandemic. This outcome will benefita total of 60,000people. The project will benefita total of 60,000peopleand will be implemented in the same districts as DEC phase 1 in Puntland and Somaliland while the project target Kismayo district of Lower Juba region. Oxfam continues to work with WASDA in this project and implementationmodalitywill remain mixed approach.  The activities are in line with Oxfam’s Humanitarian Strategy forSomalia and contributes to our Oxfam Coutnry Strategy (OSC)2020-2025.

title: CO-Drought & Sever Water Shortages Respo
description:
2020 was one of the hardest years for Somalia in decades. Flooding, COVID-19 and recurring locust invasions heavily impacted on theeconomy and livelihoods of people. The government implemented measures to contain COVID-19, including the closure of schools, reduction of movement and other economic activities. The coastal areas of Puntland and Somaliland were also hit by cyclone Gati in November 2020, resulting in a sharp increase in humanitarian needs which many organizations - including Oxfam Somalia - responded to. While the performance of the 2020 Gu rain was near normal, the Deyr rain of 2020 has been categorized a complete failure due to the La Nina conditions. These developments triggered severe water shortages in many regions and districts in Somalia. Since October 2020, regional administrations, communities and other humanitarian agencies have been sending alerts about looming drought conditions in many parts of Somalia.Oxfam’s feedback hotline continues to receive a high number of calls from people requesting immediate water interventions. These callers are mainly from the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer regions. UNOCHA assessment findings indicate that over 50% of the communities in the assessed locations reported displacement of people due to water shortages, 85% raised major concerns on watershortages, and 14 out of 40 villages reported an increase in diarrheal cases. The price of water has already more than doubled. According to Oxfam’s own market assessment, one barrel of water is currently being sold at an average of USD 4.5 per barrel, with some villages reporting over USD 7 per barrel. This is forcing the most vulnerable households to travel long distances to fetch water and/or opt for poor water quality and risk their lives. The most affected communities include IDPs and low-income host communities. Women and girls are at risk of protection-related risks as they travel in search of water.
Regarding COVID-19, over 4,784 cases with over 130 fatalities were registered by the WHO in Somalia since the start of the pandemic, with many cases left undetected due to asymptomatic infections, low testing capacity and the stigmatisation of COVID-19 cases among the population. The second wave of the pandemic seems to have also hit the country as the number of cases started to increase in the last few months. The government of Somaliahas eased most of the restrictions in August 2020 and most of the public services have resumed. This increases the risk of vulnerability to COVID-19 and the shortages of water in many areas further restrict the communities' ability to frequently wash their hands with soap. This might create a favourable environment for COVID-19 to spread.
The Ministry of Water Development in Somaliland shareda request with all humanitarian agencies, indicating that over 196,848 people are in need of urgent water interventions and that many others also require quick rehabilitations of their water sources. Over 88% of the people in need are from the Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer regions of Eastern Somaliland. In October 2020, Oxfam using the ECHO crisis modifier budget reached the most vulnerable 1,800 HH (10,800 people) in Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer for 30 days with WASH interventions. Since then, we have continued to advocate for urgent interventions by sharing summary reports with the Somalia WASH cluster and presentations of the situation with cluster members. Utilising other existing resources, we are also working with the Ministry of Water Resources to rehabilitate boreholes that were identified as strategic wells by the government.

title: Innovative Fishery Development
description:
The first component is aimed at capacity building. At least 40 beneficiaries (at least 30% female) including fishermen and women, fishmongers will undergo a maximum of six months theoretical and practical training. Youth fishermen and women will be trained on safety at sea, fishing gear mending and repairs, safe fishing methods and fish preservation, cooperatives establishment and fish quality assurance. Fishmongers, who will mostly be women, will be trained in various topics including fish handling and preservation, fishprocessing, personal hygiene, value addition (processing, grading, and packaging) and small business management. Entrepreneurship will be an integral part of the courses in order to leverage the entrepreneurship capacity
The second component is aimed at supporting the establishment/ strengthening of fishery organizations. The target beneficiaries will be organized in Self Help Groups (SHGs). The SHG is a rights-based approach which views poverty as the denial of rights and poverty alleviation as a process of reclaiming one’s rights. Given the multi-dimensional nature of poverty, the SHG Approach puts equal emphasis on the goals of economic, social andpolitical empowerment . Therefore, the established/strengthened SHGs will have the potential to empower small-scale fishers againstsome of the environmental and socioeconomic shocks such as fish catch shortfalls and revenues, sickness and death in their families, natural disasters and hunger. The 30 young fishermen will be organized intoat least 5 SHGs and will be trained/ oriented on the operations of the SHGs
The third component will support the distribution of fishing kits/gear to the SHGs including women fishmongers.Midway through the training, the project beneficiaries will be provided with fishing gears in their SGHs. Such gear may include boats and other necessary tools. On the other hand, women fishmongers, will have business start-up kits including refrigerators and basic fish processing tools. The fishing kits/ gear will be owned and managed jointly in the SHGs.
The fourth component will focus on learning and knowledge management through value chain research. In order to ensure systematic market mapping in the fishing sector, understand actors, market share, capacity gaps, and other relevant value chain information, the project will undertake a robust research on fish value chain. The research will aim to bring out suitable models to link small holders to input and output markets and improve the benefits that fishermen and women and other resource-poor value chain actors derive from the chain. Knowledge generated from the research will be disseminated to different relevant stakeholders in the sector. It will also act as a building block for future scaling efforts of the project. As Oxfam and the partner have both long-term livelihood strategies, the research finding would beused for future programing.

title: CO-Rapid Assessment CFM
description:
Oxfam’s commitment is to actively centre the voice and experience of people and community in all our work and consider power, privilege and equity in the design of community-based feedback and complaints mechanisms CBFCMS, and to respect the knowledge, wisdom andperspective of others, as there is always scope for Oxfam to grow and learn as an organisation working with communities.
Functionalfeedback and complaints mechanisms that are accessible and safe to use are a demonstration of our organization-wide accountability commitment, to be truly accountable to the people and communities we work with and those affected by our programmes, by ensuring that they understand what is appropriate and inappropriate conduct of our staff and partners, getting their feedback about our programmes and/or complaints about conduct of our staff, agents or partners  and taking appropriate action to address these concerns. Accountability is “the process of using power responsibly, taking account of, and being held accountable by different stakeholders, and primarily those who are affected by the exercise of such power” . It is the right to be heard, and the duty to respond.

However, anecdotal information indicates that where CBFCMs initiatives and experiences exist in Oxfam, many are still disjointed, some are uncoordinated, and largely undocumented. In many places, they are non-existent, or if they are, not all of them are fully functional. The design of Oxfam’s CBFCMs by Affiliates, Country Offices and in part Partners has not always ensured community involvement, in most cases resulting in not fit for purpose mechanisms. Also different affiliates still approach the issue of CBFCMs differently with different emphasis, approaches, tools and resources, therefore lacking a standardised coordinated approach.

Although Oxfam prides itself for encouraging communities we work with to speak out and report PSEA and child protection concerns and incidents concerning them,recent reports in some countries like DRC, Ethiopia, and Uganda not only attests to the limited awareness at community level on SEAand child protection risks and reporting mechanisms, but has also led to an increase in attention to ensure that SEA and child abuse and exploitation by humanitarian and development organisations like Oxfam are addressed through investment in preventive approaches but also responding to reports of abuse and exploitation when these incidents are reported.
Oxfam has two responsibilities for accountability in the programmes it manages, holding a responsibility for mutual accountability with its partners (as do the partners) and also holding a shared or joint accountability (with its partners) to the communities affected by its programmes. There is lack of knowledge how the
In addition to some of the above challenges, COVID-19 has added additional challenges to how effective current CBFCMs are, placing additional barriers to reporting that are currently not fully understood or risks mitigated.
OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT:
1. Map out existing CBCM’s initiatives in select field/project locations, and document best practices and lessons learnt in implementing CBFCMs across the Oxfam confederation
2. Undertake a rapid assessment of the existing CBFCMs in Oxfam terms of effectiveness, experiences and lessons plus existing gaps.

title: Somalia - Water for Agro-pastoral Productivity and Resilience
description: The development objective of the Water for Agro-Pastoral Productivity and Resilience Project for Somalia is to develop water and agricultural services among agro-pastoralist communities in dryland areas of Somalia. The project comprises of four components. The first component, support the development of multiple use water sources will finance investments in key water management infrastructure for harvesting, storing, and delivering water for people, livestock, and agriculture. It consists of following sub-components: (i) construction of new community water points; and (ii) rehabilitation of community water points. The second component, institutional and capacity development will help build a strong foundation for a gradual transition to more integrated and sustainable agriculture and water development - promoting the farmers adoption of drought-resistant seed varieties and climate-smart technologies - by strengthening local, state, and national institutions and capacities. It consists of following sub-components: (i) national and state institutional capacity building; and (ii) community development and demand mobilization. The third component, supporting sustainable land management and livelihoods development around water points will catalyze priority investments, facilitated by participating Federal Member States (FMS) line ministries, to create and strengthen productive livelihoods among target communities. It consists of following sub-components: (i) integrated landscape management; and (ii) agriculture and livestock support. The fourth component, project management, monitoring and evaluation (M and E), knowledge management, and learning will finance the operational costs of the project management units in participating FMS and Somaliland, as well as project coordination and fiduciary support at the Federal Republic of Somalia (FRS) level. It consists of following

title: Somalia Capacity Advancement, Livelihoods and Entrepreneurship, through Digital Uplift Project (SCALED-UP)
description: The development objective of Capacity Advancement, Livelihoods and Entrepreneurship through Digital Uplift Project for Somalia is to support progress towards increased access to basic digital financial and government services targeting entrepreneurship and employment, particularly for women. This project has three components. 1) The first component, Strengthening Institutions, is focused on stabilizing core government functions enabling access to services for individuals and businesses. 2) The second component, Enabling Financial and Digital Services, focuses on increasing individuals and businesses access to services that expand economic opportunities and help restore resilience in a gender-sensitive manner. 3) The third component, Project Management and Coordination, aims to fund project management and coordination activities.

title: Somali Integrated Statistics and Economic Planning Capacity Building
description: The objective of the Somali Integrated Statistics and Economic Planning Capacity Building Project for Somalia is to strengthen the national statistical system in the collection, processing and dissemination of poverty and selected macro-economic data to inform development policy and poverty reduction activities. The Project has four components. 1. Strengthening coordination, statistical infrastructure and data development of the national statistical system component will provide support to the client's key official statistics producing agencies in strengthening the capacity of the country's National statistical system (NSS) to collect data for poverty and macroeconomic monitoring. 1.1. Supporting the Development and Coordination of the NSS subcomponent will support the strengthening of the recipient's legal and organizational framework for the NSS as well as statistical infrastructure. 1.2. Somali Integrated Household Budget Survey subcomponent will support the design and implementation of the Somali Integrated Household Budget Survey (SIHBS) for monitoring welfare, providing macroeconomic baselines and establishing a baseline survey for a frequent data collection system. 1.3. Strengthening Sources of Business and Administrative Data needed for the Compilation of National Accounts and Key Social Statistics subcomponent will address key data gaps needed to produce quality national accounts statistics that meet the basics of the System of National Accounts 2008 (SNA2008) and other international statistical standards. 1.4. Strengthening Human Capacity in Poverty, Consumer Price Index (CPI) and National Accounts Statistics subcomponent will support the training of staff to compile poverty indicators and indexes as well as to draw poverty lines, using new data from the poverty survey and new CPI. 1.5. Development of a Compendium of Statistical Concepts and Definitions, Dat

title: Shock Responsive Safety Net for Human Capital Project
description: The development objective of Shock Responsive Safety Net for Human Capital Project for Somalia is to provide cash transfers to targeted poor and vulnerable households and establish the key building blocks of a national shock-responsive safety net system. This project has three components. 1) The first component, Nutrition-linked Unconditional Cash Transfers, aims to provide unconditional cash transfers to households that are chronically poor and vulnerable to drought and malnutrition and link them to complementary nutritional support programs. 2) The second component, Delivery Systems and Institutional Capacity Building, aims to establish the key building blocks of a Social Protection (SP) delivery system, advance policy development, and strengthen institutional capacity of relevant government ministries to manage and implement it. 3) The third component, Project Management, Monitoring and Evaluation, and Knowledge Management, aims to establish a Project Implementation Unit (PIU), strengthen Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs (MoLSA's) coordination arrangements, promote learning and knowledge management through robust monitoring and evaluation, and support the design of a pilot productive safety net activity targeted at youth.

title: Somalia Reengagement and Reform Development Policy Financing
description: This Program Document proposes a Reengagement and Reform Development Policy Financing (DPF) for the Federal Republic of Somalia in the amount of US dollar 420 million from International Development Association (IDA) grant resources. The objectives of the proposed DPF are to facilitate full normalization of relations with the World Bank Group (WBG) and support Somalia's economic recovery through policy reforms that strengthen fiscal management and promote inclusive private sector-led growth. Up to SDR 271.2 (up to US dollar 375 million equivalent) of the proposed grant will be disbursed to the bridge-loan creditor assisting with arrears clearance (‘Portion A of the Financing’); and SDR 32.6 million (US dollar 45 million equivalent) will be disbursed to the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) as budget support to meet cash flow needs after Somalia has cleared its arrears to IDA (‘Portion B of the Financing’). The DPF complements a rapidly expanding engagement to build human capital and strengthen resilience to climate change and other shocks. In FY2020, the World Bank is currently delivering technical assistance to develop livestock insurance, a major Urbanization Review, and upstream analysis on health and education that are expected to inform new financing. The DPF also addresses the above challenges by enabling full reengagement with the WBG. The DPF will facilitate Somalia's clearance of arrears to IDA, which is a requirement to qualify for international debt relief under the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative. Full reengagement with the international community through the HIPC process is expected to enable Somalia to access the financial and technical support the country needs for sustained poverty reduction and inclusive economic growth. Normalization of Somalia's relationship with IDA would give the government's access to financing from IDA's Crisi

title: Shock Responsive Safety Net for Locust Response Project
Integrating Sexual and Reproductive Health Services in Bosaso
description: The programme through a contribution to Médecins du Monde-France aims at improving access to sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services for the population of Bosaso (Puntland, Somalia). This will be done through progressively integrating the SRH into existing primary health care services offered in health facilities. Regional health authorities as well as local health providers are closely involved in the intervention to not only ensure that services are culturally responsive but also that they become an integral part of the health system.
